Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: Custody of Vaughn concerns standards for initial custody determinations and the requirement of explicit findings regarding domestic violence and its effects on the child. It does not interpret G.L. c. 208, § 28, nor does it address what constitutes a "material and substantial change in circumstances" for purposes of modifying an existing judgment. Using Vaughn as authority for the existence of a post‑judgment material change under § 28 therefore misstates the scope of the decision.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above."

Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition that such a material and substantial change has occurred since a prior judgment.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: It is well settled that a judgment awarding alimony or a division of marital property which is supported by findings necessary to sustain it will not be set aside unless those findings are “plainly wrong.” King v. King, 373 Mass. 37, 40 (1977). Angelone v. Angelone, supra at 729. See Mass.R.Dom.Rel.P. 52(a) (1975). A trial judge “has broad discretion in awarding alimony after he has considered all the statutory factors.” Bahceli v. Bahceli, supra at 449.

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).proposition: Since entry of the Judgment on March 15, 2022, a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred within the meaning of G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related case law, including Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); and Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).support_reasoning: The proposition invokes Schuler as authority for the general requirement that a party seeking modification of alimony or child support must show a material and substantial change in circumstances under G.L. c. 208, § 28 and related law. Schuler squarely states and applies that rule, affirming denial of modification because the husband failed to prove the requisite material change, and discusses the nature of income and asset changes that may or may not satisfy the standard. Although the case ultimately finds no sufficient change on its facts, it clearly supports the legal principle about the change‑in‑circumstances requirement.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment… In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … A substantial and permanent decrease in the income of the support provider is one of the material circumstances to be considered in a request for reduction of a support award.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: In determining custody and parenting time, the Court’s “paramount concern is the best interests of the child.”
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly characterizes the governing standard in custody matters as the “best interests of the child” and describes that standard as the paramount concern in such determinations, citing earlier Massachusetts precedent. The court affirms that in deciding custody and parenting time under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), the judge must weigh all relevant factors to determine the child’s best interests, making this case solid authority for the proposition stated.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt…; Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

App. Ct. 237 (2.support_reasoning: The case is an initial custody determination, not a complaint for modification based on changed circumstances, and it does not discuss the legal standard for modifying an existing judgment. Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237 (2.relevant_excerpt: “[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future…. The decision of which parent will promote a child’s best interests ‘is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.’” (50 Mass. App. Ct. at 243)

Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 215 (2002)
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that modification of a custody or parenting-time order is warranted when a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and modification is necessary to serve the child’s best interests.
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does address modification, but only in the context of alimony/support, not custody or parenting time. The court recites the standard as requiring a demonstrated change in circumstances after the original decree and emphasizes the judge’s discretion; it does not discuss custody or best interests of the child in the modification section, nor articulate a “material and substantial change” plus “best interests” test for modifying custody or parenting-time orders. Therefore it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In considering Joyce’s argument on appeal, we are mindful of our standard of review. As stated in Heistand v. Heistand, 384 Mass. 20, 26-27 (1981): ‘In the interests of finality this court has conditioned modification upon a demonstrated change in circumstances after entry of the original decree. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). The determination of the extent and palpability of such change, however, lies in large measure within the discretion of the trial judge.’”

The proposition about the father’s noncompliance with educational responsibilities and the dysfunction of joint educational decision‑making finds no support in this case’s facts, reasoning, or holding.

“The Court finds that the educational system of the Newton public schools is superior to the educational system of the Tucson public schools, hence it is beneficial for [the son] to remain in the Newton system.”

It therefore does not provide authority for the specific educational‑decision‑making proposition claimed.

T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion is about child support in a shared physical custody context and does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 208, § 31, nor does it address allocation of decision‑making responsibility (legal custody) based on which parent is more likely to carry out the child’s education‑related needs. The only education‑related portion simply allocates financial responsibility for private school; it does not discuss decision‑making authority or parental cooperation in making best‑interest decisions. Thus, the case does not support the stated proposition.
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The judgment required that the mother continue to provide medical and dental insurance for the child if available through her employer and that she be responsible for the costs of the child’s uninsured medical and dental expenses, child care, and extracurricular activities. The order provided also that the child was to attend public school in the school district in which the mother resides, and that if the mother wished the child to attend private school instead, she would bear the cost.
